map.domains: (topic delay-d) (map mapgroup-d) (topic indexing-d) (map glossref-d) (topic hi-d) (topic ut-d) (topic hazard-d) (topic abbrev-d) (topic pr-d) (topic sw-d) (topic ui-d)

topicmeta.shortdesc: CWRC-Writer has a simple and straight forward process to login that requires a user name and password.

topicmeta.navtitle: Open a document or template from the landing page
topicmeta.linktext: Open a document or template from the landing page
topicmeta.shortdesc: In the start-up menu of CWRC-Writer, users can choose one of the templates available when starting to work in CWRC-Writer.

topicmeta.navtitle: Open a document or template from toolbar
topicmeta.linktext: Open a document or template from toolbar
topicmeta.shortdesc: If a document/template is already open you can switch to or open another document / template at any time.

topicmeta.navtitle: Deleting text from the structure panel
topicmeta.linktext: Deleting text from the structure panel
topicmeta.shortdesc: CWRC-Writer templates open with pre-existing text. It may be easier to first delete the text (but not the tags) before adding your own text to the document.

topicmeta.navtitle: Writing in the text area of CWRC-Writer with your cursor
topicmeta.linktext: Writing in the text area of CWRC-Writer with your cursor
topicmeta.shortdesc: There are multiple ways to begin writing text in CWRC-Writer. You can select a tag and then begin to write, or you can place your cursor in the editor and begin to type.

topicmeta.navtitle: Writing in the text area of CWRC-Writer by selecting a tag
topicmeta.linktext: Writing in the text area of CWRC-Writer by selecting a tag
topicmeta.shortdesc: There are multiple ways to begin writing text in CWRC-Writer. You can select a tag and then begin to write, or you can place your cursor in the editor and begin to type.

CWRC-Writer allows you to save documents you have created on our server as temporary test files to work with. At the moment, however, we do not have individual authentication setup for each user, so it's best if you do not play with each other's files: this way each tester can have his/her own files to alter, add to, and so forth.
the validation of your text against the appropriate XML schema is working, but only in part, because we are still working out the relationship between the entity annotations and the markup.

The validation of your text against the appropriate XML schema for the document. If your document is invalid a pop-up will appear at the bottom of the page with a list of errors found in the document.
You can edit the header...
There is an option to change the different editor modes for your document. Editor modes control what tagging will be allowed in your document (a combination of XML and RDF).
Show tags allows you to view all the XML tags in the document.
View Source is for users who wish to view the raw XML or RDF code.
Edit Source is for users who wish to edit the raw XML or RDF code. We do not suggest that you use this option unless you are an expert.
Copy and paste text into CWRC-Writer, can be achieved in two ways. The first one can be acieved by highlighting text in the text area.

Copying and pasting multiple tags within CWRC-Writer is the fastest way to build up a document. Whether you are adding poem lines or more notes, you can create entire sections of structure in a few easy steps.

topicmeta.navtitle: Copying and pasting a single tag
topicmeta.linktext: Copying and pasting a single tag
topicmeta.shortdesc: Copying and pasting a tag allow you to duplicate structure and/or content with minimal effort. This acts as a type of shortcut tor producing content in you document.

topicmeta.navtitle: Copying and pasting text in the structure panel
topicmeta.linktext: Copying and pasting text in the structure panel
topicmeta.shortdesc: This is how users can copy and paste text into CWRC-Writer by selecting a tag in the structure panel.

topicmeta.navtitle: Viewing information copied from the structure panel
topicmeta.linktext: Viewing information copied from the structure panel
topicmeta.shortdesc: CWRC-Writer provides the option of looking at what you have copied in the structure panel before you need to paste it in. This allows you to make sure you have selected exactly what you wanted to work with.

topicmeta.navtitle: Copying and pasting entities in the editor
topicmeta.linktext: Copying and pasting entities in the editor
topicmeta.shortdesc: YOu can copy and paste entities in CWRC-Writer. This will let you replicate entitied is you have multiple instances of that tag in the document.

topicmeta.navtitle: Adding structural tags by selecting text
topicmeta.linktext: Adding structural tags by selecting text
topicmeta.shortdesc: In each document that you work with there is a pre-existing XML template that contains the basic tags necessary for that type of document. You can add new structural tags to the document easily.

topicmeta.navtitle: Deleting tags using the CWRC-Writer toolbar
topicmeta.linktext: Deleting tags using the CWRC-Writer toolbar
topicmeta.shortdesc: The document template that you are working with may have existing tags that you do not need for your document. You can easily delete these tags following these steps.
You can edit any of the tags that pre-exist in the template or that you have added to the document. This also allows you to add contextual information to the tags in your document .

topicmeta.navtitle: Editing tags in the structure menu
topicmeta.linktext: Editing tags in the structure menu
topicmeta.shortdesc: You can edit any of the tags that pre-exist in the template or that you have added to the document. This also allows you to add contextual information through attributes.

topicmeta.navtitle: Editing tags using the CWRC-Writer toolbar
topicmeta.linktext: Editing tags using the CWRC-Writer toolbar
topicmeta.shortdesc: You can edit any of the tags that pre-exist in the template or that you have added to the document. This also allows you to add additional information to the tags in your document (E.g. next, rend, etc.).
The document template that you are working with may have existing tags that you do not need for your document. You can easily delete these tags following these steps.

topicmeta.navtitle: Adding structural tags in the structural panel
topicmeta.linktext: Adding structural tags in the structural panel
topicmeta.shortdesc: In each document that you enter there is a pre-existing XML template that contains the basic tags necessary for that type document. You can add new structural tags to the document easily.
The "Tag Person" option is for tagging people by name. It usually contains a proper noun or noun phrase, but can also contain pronouns or other ways of referring to someone.
Tag place is for tagging a place. It can describe both a geological location or a setting.
The "Tag Date" is for tagging a date in the text. This tag can contain the year, month, day or a combination of the three.
The "Tag Organization" entity is used to tag an organization or company.
The "Tag Text/Title" entity is for tagging a title or the text of any type of work
The "Tag Link" entity is for tagging any links or URL found in the document.
The "Tag Keyword" entity is tagging any important keywords in your document.
The "Tag Correction" entity is used to tag any correction you have made to the original text.
Notes must be applied to a span of text. They cannot be inserted into the text without the cursor having selected something, although they will be in the future.
tag citation is for tagging citations in the text, which may contain a loosely structured bibliographic citation of which the subcomponents may or may not be explicitly tagged.

The CWRC-Writer templates come with pre existing entities as examples to new users. You can easily delete these entities or any entities that you don't want in your document from within the editor (using right-click).

topicmeta.navtitle: Deleting entities from the entities panel
topicmeta.linktext: Deleting entities from the entities panel
topicmeta.shortdesc: The CWRC-Writer templates come with pre existing entities as examples to new users. You can easily delete these entities or any entities that you don't want in you document or those you have mistakenly added from the entities panel.
The CWRC-Writer templates come with pre existing entities as example to new users. You can easily delete these entities or any entities that you don't want in your document from the toolbar.
You can add qualifying information to the RDF entities added to the document. You can edit the entities within the editor by right-clicking. This information can be edited at any time.

topicmeta.navtitle: Editing entities from the entities panel
topicmeta.linktext: Editing entities from the entities panel
topicmeta.shortdesc: You can add qualifying information to the RDF entities within the document. You can edit the entities in the entity column on the left side of the editor. This information can be edited at any time.
You can add qualifying information to the RDF entities in the document. You can edit the entities from the toolbar at any time.

CWRC-Writer allows you to add RDF entities to your document. You can add these tags from within the editor using your mouse right-click button. When you add RDF entities to the document you are also adding a corresponding XML tag to the document.

CWRC-Writer allows you to add RDF entities to your document. You can add these tags from the toolbar using icon buttons. When you add RDF entities to the document you are also adding a corresponding XML tag to the document.

You can add relationships between the tagged entities within the document. You connect these entities with predicates, pre existing ones occure or you can add your own. This lets you create a semantic web of information within your document.
If you have mistakenly added a relation, you can delete them in the left column.

task.domains: (topic task) (topic hi-d) (topic ut-d) (topic indexing-d) (topic hazard-d) (topic abbrev-d) (topic pr-d) (topic sw-d) (topic ui-d)
task.title: Logging in to CWRC-Writer
task.shortdesc: CWRC-Writer has a simple and straight forward process to login that requires a user name and password.

copyright.copyrholder: Use of this public-domain resource is governed by the Creative Commons Attribution-NonCommercial 4.0 International License

context.p: These instructions are for the standalone version of CWRC-Writer. If you would like to test CWCR-Writer, please contact us at cwrc@ualberta.ca

taskbody.prereq: CWRC-Writer is only optimized for FireFox or Google Chrome browsers. Please open CWRC-Writer in either of the options only.

step.cmd: Open the CWRC-Writer URL in your browser: http://apps.testing.cwrc.ca/editor/test/index.htm
Enter your user name and password in the pop-up login box.
step.info: For the testing version of CWRC-Writer everyone has the same login information. User name: cwrc Password: cwrcy

task.domains: (topic task) (topic hi-d) (topic ut-d) (topic indexing-d) (topic hazard-d) (topic abbrev-d) (topic pr-d) (topic sw-d) (topic ui-d)
task.title: Open a document or template from the landing page
task.shortdesc: In the start-up menu of CWRC-Writer, users can choose one of the templates available when starting to work in CWRC-Writer.

copyright.copyrholder: Use of this public-domain resource is governed by the Creative Commons Attribution-NonCommercial 4.0 International License

step.cmd: Click on the template that you would like to work with.
step.info: The title of the template is a button that will automatically load the document you selected in CWRC-Writer.
step.stepresult: This will open a new document that you can begin working with.

task.domains: (topic task) (topic hi-d) (topic ut-d) (topic indexing-d) (topic hazard-d) (topic abbrev-d) (topic pr-d) (topic sw-d) (topic ui-d) (topic task strictTaskbody-c)
task.title: Open a document or template from toolbar
task.shortdesc: If a document/template is already open you can switch to or open another document / template at any time.

copyright.copyrholder: Use of this public-domain resource is governed by the Creative Commons Attribution-NonCommercial 4.0 International License

step.cmd: Select the "Load button on the CWRC-Writer toolbar.
Click on the document/template you would like to open from the popup list.

taskbody.result: By selecting a document / template from the list in the pop-up a new page will be reloaded. If you have not saved your information prior to opening a different document you will lose any changes that you have made.

task.domains: (topic task) (topic hi-d) (topic ut-d) (topic indexing-d) (topic hazard-d) (topic abbrev-d) (topic pr-d) (topic sw-d) (topic ui-d) (topic task strictTaskbody-c)
task.title: Deleting text from the structure panel
task.shortdesc: CWRC-Writer templates open with pre-existing text. It may be easier to first delete the text (but not the tags) before adding your own text to the document.

copyright.copyrholder: Use of this public-domain resource is governed by the Creative Commons Attribution-NonCommercial 4.0 International License

step.cmd: Click on the tag that contains the text that you would like to delete.
Right-click on the selected tag and choose "Remove Content Only"
step.info: If you would like to delete the tag and the content choose "Remove tag and all content" option from the right-click menu.

taskbody.result: This will remove the content from this tag, but it will leave the tag in the document.

task.domains: (topic task) (topic hi-d) (topic ut-d) (topic indexing-d) (topic hazard-d) (topic abbrev-d) (topic pr-d) (topic sw-d) (topic ui-d) (topic task strictTaskbody-c)
task.title: Writing in the text area of CWRC-Writer with your cursor
task.shortdesc: There are multiple ways to begin writing text in CWRC-Writer. You can select a tag and then begin to write, or you can place your cursor in the editor and begin to type.

copyright.copyrholder: Use of this public-domain resource is governed by the Creative Commons Attribution-NonCommercial 4.0 International License

step.cmd: Select a range of text you would like to remove or place your cursor in the editor where you would like to add text.

taskbody.result: You can then begin to write in CWRC WriterIf you create a new "p" tag in the prose document, but then decide to work on something else in the document without entering text, you must then double click on that "p" tag before you can enter text into it. If you single click only and then write, you will delete the tag.

task.domains: (topic task) (topic hi-d) (topic ut-d) (topic indexing-d) (topic hazard-d) (topic abbrev-d) (topic pr-d) (topic sw-d) (topic ui-d)
task.title: Writing in the text area of CWRC-Writer by selecting a tag
task.shortdesc: There are multiple ways to begin writing text in CWRC-Writer. You can select a tag and then begin to write, or you can place your cursor in the editor and begin to type.

copyright.copyrholder: Use of this public-domain resource is governed by the Creative Commons Attribution-NonCommercial 4.0 International License

taskbody.context: You can begin typing text by first selecting a tag in the structure panel. this allows you to make sure in exactly what tag you are writing in.

step.cmd: In the structure panel, double click (so that the tag is bolded and italicized) on the tag in which you would like to type.
Once you have selected the tag you want to type in, begin typing.

taskbody.result: The text will be entered in the tag you have selected, any content that previously existed in that tag will be erased.

task.domains: (topic task) (topic hi-d) (topic ut-d) (topic indexing-d) (topic hazard-d) (topic abbrev-d) (topic pr-d) (topic sw-d) (topic ui-d) (topic task strictTaskbody-c)
task.title: Saving your document
task.shortdesc: CWRC-Writer allows you to save documents you have created on our server as temporary test files to work with. At the moment, however, we do not have individual authentication setup for each user, so it's best if you do not play with each other's files: this way each tester can have his/her own files to alter, add to, and so forth.

copyright.copyrholder: Use of this public-domain resource is governed by the Creative Commons Attribution-NonCommercial 4.0 International License

step.cmd: Click on the "Save" toolbar button.
Enter the title of the document, and click "Save."
step.info: Adding your initials to the beginning (e.g. MS) is a good way to indicate to others that it is a file created by another CWRC-Writer tester. You may only enter upper or lowercase letter; no numbers, spaces, or punctuation are allowed.

step.cmd: Once you clicked on "Save," the document validates and is successfully saved.
step.info: If the document is not valid, a pop-up will appear and you will be asked if you would like to save anyway.

task.domains: (topic task) (topic hi-d) (topic ut-d) (topic indexing-d) (topic hazard-d) (topic abbrev-d) (topic pr-d) (topic sw-d) (topic ui-d) (topic task strictTaskbody-c)
task.title: Validating your document
task.shortdesc: the validation of your text against the appropriate XML schema is working, but only in part, because we are still working out the relationship between the entity annotations and the markup.

copyright.copyrholder: Use of this public-domain resource is governed by the Creative Commons Attribution-NonCommercial 4.0 International License

step.cmd: Click on the "Validate" button in the toolbar.
A pop-up from the bottom of the editor appears. It will tell you if the document is valid or not.
step.info: If the document is invalid, the pop-up will list the errors in the document. To find out more about Validation, please go to the TEI website here: http://tbe.kantl.be/TBE/xquery/TBEvalidator.xg

task.domains: (topic task) (topic hi-d) (topic ut-d) (topic indexing-d) (topic hazard-d) (topic abbrev-d) (topic pr-d) (topic sw-d) (topic ui-d) (topic task strictTaskbody-c)
task.title: Checking your invalid document
task.shortdesc: The validation of your text against the appropriate XML schema for the document. If your document is invalid a pop-up will appear at the bottom of the page with a list of errors found in the document.

copyright.copyrholder: Use of this public-domain resource is governed by the Creative Commons Attribution-NonCommercial 4.0 International License

step.cmd: When you click on the "Validate" document and the document is invalid a pop-up appears with error messages.
Click on one of the error, this will highlight the error in the document. You can then correct the invalid structure.
step.info: You can still save the document if it is invalid, but a pop-up will appear making sure that you want to proceed.

task.domains: (topic task) (topic hi-d) (topic ut-d) (topic indexing-d) (topic hazard-d) (topic abbrev-d) (topic pr-d) (topic sw-d) (topic ui-d) (topic task strictTaskbody-c)
task.title: Editing the header
task.shortdesc: You can edit the header...

copyright.copyrholder: Use of this public-domain resource is governed by the Creative Commons Attribution-NonCommercial 4.0 International License

step.cmd: Click on the "teiHeader" tag in the left structure column.
Edit the header in a pop-up that appears. Once you have finished click on the "OK."

task.domains: (topic task) (topic hi-d) (topic ut-d) (topic indexing-d) (topic hazard-d) (topic abbrev-d) (topic pr-d) (topic sw-d) (topic ui-d) (topic task strictTaskbody-c)
task.title: Switching modes
task.shortdesc: There is an option to change the different editor modes for your document. Editor modes control what tagging will be allowed in your document (a combination of XML and RDF).

copyright.copyrholder: Use of this public-domain resource is governed by the Creative Commons Attribution-NonCommercial 4.0 International License

step.cmd: Click on the "Settings" button on the top right top of the editor

Select your preferred editor mode from the drop-down menu and click on "OK." This will change the editor mode for your document. There are three editor modes in CWRC-Writer, based on the treatment of overlap.
step.info: The default mode is XML and RDF - no overlap. If you wish to switch between the three options, go to "Settings" (in the top right corner), choose the option you would like to work with, click on "OK" and begin to work with your document.If you have overlapping tags in your document, you cannot switch to one of the other two modes.

task.domains: (topic task) (topic hi-d) (topic ut-d) (topic indexing-d) (topic hazard-d) (topic abbrev-d) (topic pr-d) (topic sw-d) (topic ui-d) (topic task strictTaskbody-c)
task.title: Showing tags in editor
task.shortdesc: Show tags allows you to view all the XML tags in the document.

copyright.copyrholder: Use of this public-domain resource is governed by the Creative Commons Attribution-NonCommercial 4.0 International License

step.cmd: Click on the "Settings" button on the top right top of the editor.
Click on the "Show Tags" check box button and click on "OK." This will show all the XML tags in the document.

task.domains: (topic task) (topic hi-d) (topic ut-d) (topic indexing-d) (topic hazard-d) (topic abbrev-d) (topic pr-d) (topic sw-d) (topic ui-d) (topic task strictTaskbody-c)
task.title: View Source
task.shortdesc: View Source is for users who wish to view the raw XML or RDF code.

copyright.copyrholder: Use of this public-domain resource is governed by the Creative Commons Attribution-NonCommercial 4.0 International License

step.cmd: Click on the "View Source" toolbar icon.
The view source pop-up appears, once you have finished looking over the code, click on the "OK" button.

task.domains: (topic task) (topic hi-d) (topic ut-d) (topic indexing-d) (topic hazard-d) (topic abbrev-d) (topic pr-d) (topic sw-d) (topic ui-d) (topic task strictTaskbody-c)
task.title: Edit Source
task.shortdesc: Edit Source is for users who wish to edit the raw XML or RDF code. We do not suggest that you use this option unless you are an expert.

copyright.copyrholder: Use of this public-domain resource is governed by the Creative Commons Attribution-NonCommercial 4.0 International License

step.cmd: Click on the "Edit Source" toolbar icon.
When you click on the edit source button, a warning pop-up appears. To proceed, click on "Yes."
The edit source pop-up appears, once you have finished editing the code (again, which we do not recommend), click on the "OK" button.

task.domains: (topic task) (topic hi-d) (topic ut-d) (topic indexing-d) (topic hazard-d) (topic abbrev-d) (topic pr-d) (topic sw-d) (topic ui-d)
task.title: Copying and pasting text
task.shortdesc: Copy and paste text into CWRC-Writer, can be achieved in two ways. The first one can be acieved by highlighting text in the text area.

copyright.copyrholder: Use of this public-domain resource is governed by the Creative Commons Attribution-NonCommercial 4.0 International License

step.cmd: Copy the information that you would like to paste into CWRC-Writer.
step.info: You can copy any information from inside or outside of CWRC-Writer. All existing tags will be stripped out when the text is pasted into CWRC-Writer. CWRC-Writer only allows users to copy and paste using their keyboard shortcuts (Command C and V for Mac; Control C and V for P. C.s)

step.cmd: Activate the field you are pasting into.
step.info: To do this, highlight the text you wish to paste over within the document in the editing pane. Currently you cannot paste into multiple tags at once. For example, in the prose document you need to paste in paragraphs one "p" tag at a time (this is true for lines, notes, etc. as well).

step.cmd: Paste text in, using the keyboard shortcuts, Cmd V or Ctrl V
step.stepresult: The text will show up in to the desired field. The structure panel tags will not be affected, unless you have pasted over preexisting tags. If you do those tags will be deleted.

task.domains: (topic task) (topic hi-d) (topic ut-d) (topic indexing-d) (topic hazard-d) (topic abbrev-d) (topic pr-d) (topic sw-d) (topic ui-d)
task.title: Copying and pasting multiple tags
task.shortdesc: Copying and pasting multiple tags within CWRC-Writer is the fastest way to build up a document. Whether you are adding poem lines or more notes, you can create entire sections of structure in a few easy steps.

copyright.copyrholder: Use of this public-domain resource is governed by the Creative Commons Attribution-NonCommercial 4.0 International License

taskbody.context: You can copy any tag that exists in the document and the tags that are nested below it.

step.cmd: To copy and paste a parent tag and all the tags nested within it, the user needs to click twice on a tag (until it is bolded and italicized) and use your keyboard shortcut to copy.

info.note: CWRC-Writer only allows users to copy and paste using their keyboard shortcuts (Command C and V for Macs; Control C and V for P. C.s)

step.cmd: Right-click on a tag in the structure panel and choose one of the "Insert Options." Depending on which option you chose this will insert a tag, before, after, or inside the tag you have selected.
step.info: To paste the tags in the document, we suggest first inserting a new tag into which you can paste.

step.cmd: Select the tag you have just added to the document until it is bolded and italicized. Use your keyboard shortcut to paste.

taskbody.example:
In the poem document you can click on a "lg" tag (until it is bolded and italicized) and use your keyboard shortcut (Command or Control C) to copy that tag.
Then insert a new "lg" tag by bolding the last one in the list and choosing the right-click option "Insert tag After" (in this case choosing to insert a new "lg" tag).
When you choose to add a "lg" tag, this will create an empty tag that you can then paste the structure into; click on the tag (until it is bolded) and paste the information in. Success! You have pasted tags and text in the structure, creating a new "lg" tag with nested "l" tags.

task.domains: (topic task) (topic hi-d) (topic ut-d) (topic indexing-d) (topic hazard-d) (topic abbrev-d) (topic pr-d) (topic sw-d) (topic ui-d)
task.title: Copying and pasting a single tag
task.shortdesc: Copying and pasting a tag allow you to duplicate structure and/or content with minimal effort. This acts as a type of shortcut tor producing content in you document.

copyright.copyrholder: Use of this public-domain resource is governed by the Creative Commons Attribution-NonCommercial 4.0 International License

context.p: You can copy any single tag of your document, and paste it where ever you need to replicate that tag and/or information that tag contains.

step.cmd: To copy and paste one tag (and its content in the document) click on the tag (until the tag is bolded but not italicized) and use the keyboard shortcut to copy (Ctrl C / Cmd C).
Then select another tag or insert (using the right click menu) a tag in the structure panel, bolding the tag.
Then use Ctrl V or Cmd V to paste the single tag in.

task.domains: (topic task) (topic hi-d) (topic ut-d) (topic indexing-d) (topic hazard-d) (topic abbrev-d) (topic pr-d) (topic sw-d) (topic ui-d) (topic task strictTaskbody-c)
task.title: Copying and pasting text in the structure panel
task.shortdesc: This is how users can copy and paste text into CWRC-Writer by selecting a tag in the structure panel.

copyright.copyrholder: Use of this public-domain resource is governed by the Creative Commons Attribution-NonCommercial 4.0 International License

step.cmd: Copy the information that you would like to paste into CWRC-Writer.
Double click on the tag you wish to paste into in the structure panel until it is bolded and italicized.

info.note: If you use this method, you will delete all content currently in the tag that you are pasting into.

step.cmd: With the tag you selected highlighted, use your keyboard shortcut to paste in the copied text.

task.domains: (topic task) (topic hi-d) (topic ut-d) (topic indexing-d) (topic hazard-d) (topic abbrev-d) (topic pr-d) (topic sw-d) (topic ui-d)
task.title: Viewing information copied from the structure panel
task.shortdesc: CWRC-Writer provides the option of looking at what you have copied in the structure panel before you need to paste it in. This allows you to make sure you have selected exactly what you wanted to work with.

copyright.copyrholder: Use of this public-domain resource is governed by the Creative Commons Attribution-NonCommercial 4.0 International License

context.p: Copying information in CWRC-Writer can at times be a daunting task, but we provide the option to make sure you know exactly what you have copied before you paste it.

prereq.p: Copy a portion of text in CWRC-Writer (see instructions at:)

step.cmd: Click on the small arrow at the bottom of the CWRCWriter window/frame.
step.stepresult: This will bring up the "Validation" and "Selection" Tabs.

step.cmd: Click on the "Selection" tab.

taskbody.result: You will be able to see what you have copied, included the tags and text.

task.domains: (topic task) (topic hi-d) (topic ut-d) (topic indexing-d) (topic hazard-d) (topic abbrev-d) (topic pr-d) (topic sw-d) (topic ui-d) (topic task strictTaskbody-c)
task.title: Copying and pasting entities in the editor
task.shortdesc: YOu can copy and paste entities in CWRC-Writer. This will let you replicate entitied is you have multiple instances of that tag in the document.

step.cmd: Right-click on the entity that you wish to copy, either in the entitiescolumn or within the document.
Place your cursor in the text editor (wherever you would like the new entity to go) and right-click. Select the option to "Paste Entity."

taskbody.result: This will add a new entity in the document (you may have to delete texts as the new entity inserts beside any selected text).

task.domains: (topic task) (topic hi-d) (topic ut-d) (topic indexing-d) (topic hazard-d) (topic abbrev-d) (topic pr-d) (topic sw-d) (topic ui-d) (topic task strictTaskbody-c)
task.title: Adding structural tags by selecting text
task.shortdesc: In each document that you work with there is a pre-existing XML template that contains the basic tags necessary for that type of document. You can add new structural tags to the document easily.

copyright.copyrholder: Use of this public-domain resource is governed by the Creative Commons Attribution-NonCommercial 4.0 International License

step.cmd: Select text that you would like to add a structural tag to.
Choose a tag from the toolbar drop down menu and select it.
Once you select the tag you would like to add to the structure panel, a pop-up will appear. This allows you to add qualifying information to the tag. Once you have finished, click on "OK."
step.info: You do not have to enter any additional information you do not want to. You can just press "OK" as soon as you see this pop-up.
step.stepresult: You have now added a new structure tag. For example, in the image below you can see we have added a new "time" tag in the document structure, by following the above steps.

task.domains: (topic task) (topic hi-d) (topic ut-d) (topic indexing-d) (topic hazard-d) (topic abbrev-d) (topic pr-d) (topic sw-d) (topic ui-d) (topic task strictTaskbody-c)
task.title: Deleting tags using the CWRC-Writer toolbar
task.shortdesc: The document template that you are working with may have existing tags that you do not need for your document. You can easily delete these tags following these steps.

copyright.copyrholder: Use of this public-domain resource is governed by the Creative Commons Attribution-NonCommercial 4.0 International License

step.cmd: Highlight the text in the tag that you want to delete.
Click on the toolbar option "Remove Tag."
step.stepresult: This deletes the tag that the text belongs in. The text will remain in the editor.

task.domains: (topic task) (topic hi-d) (topic ut-d) (topic indexing-d) (topic hazard-d) (topic abbrev-d) (topic pr-d) (topic sw-d) (topic ui-d) (topic task strictTaskbody-c)
task.title: Editing tags in the editor
task.shortdesc: You can edit any of the tags that pre-exist in the template or that you have added to the document. This also allows you to add contextual information to the tags in your document .

copyright.copyrholder: Use of this public-domain resource is governed by the Creative Commons Attribution-NonCommercial 4.0 International License

step.cmd: Place your cursor within the text in the tag that you would like to delete.
Right-click on the tag that contains your cursor and select the option "Edit Tag."
A pop-up will appear that allows you to add contextual information to tags.
step.info: The difference in the list of attributes available in the pop-up will depend on the tag that you are editing.

step.cmd: Click "OK" and all edits made to the tag will be saved.

task.domains: (topic task) (topic hi-d) (topic ut-d) (topic indexing-d) (topic hazard-d) (topic abbrev-d) (topic pr-d) (topic sw-d) (topic ui-d) (topic task strictTaskbody-c)
task.title: Editing tags in the structure menu
task.shortdesc: You can edit any of the tags that pre-exist in the template or that you have added to the document. This also allows you to add contextual information through attributes.

copyright.copyrholder: Use of this public-domain resource is governed by the Creative Commons Attribution-NonCommercial 4.0 International License

step.cmd: Highlight on the tag that you would like to edit.
Right-click on the tag and select the option "Edit Tag."
A pop-up will appear that allows you to add additional information to tags.
step.info: The different attributes available in the pop-up will depend on the tag that you are editing.

step.cmd: Click "OK" and all edits made to the tag will be saved.

task.domains: (topic task) (topic hi-d) (topic ut-d) (topic indexing-d) (topic hazard-d) (topic abbrev-d) (topic pr-d) (topic sw-d) (topic ui-d) (topic task strictTaskbody-c)
task.title: Editing tags using the CWRC-Writer toolbar
task.shortdesc: You can edit any of the tags that pre-exist in the template or that you have added to the document. This also allows you to add additional information to the tags in your document (E.g. next, rend, etc.).

copyright.copyrholder: Use of this public-domain resource is governed by the Creative Commons Attribution-NonCommercial 4.0 International License

step.cmd: Highlight the text within the tag that you want to edit.
Click on the "Edit tag" toolbar option.
A pop-up will appear that allows you to add additional information to tags.
step.info: The different attributes available in the pop-up will depend on the tag that you are editing.

step.cmd: Click "OK" and all edits made to the tag will be saved.

task.domains: (topic task) (topic hi-d) (topic ut-d) (topic indexing-d) (topic hazard-d) (topic abbrev-d) (topic pr-d) (topic sw-d) (topic ui-d) (topic task strictTaskbody-c)
task.title: Deleting tags in the editor
task.shortdesc: The document template that you are working with may have existing tags that you do not need for your document. You can easily delete these tags following these steps.

copyright.copyrholder: Use of this public-domain resource is governed by the Creative Commons Attribution-NonCommercial 4.0 International License

step.cmd: Place your cursor in the text that is in the tag you want to delete. OR select the tag that you would like to delete in the structure panel.
Right-click and choose the "Remove Tag" option.

taskbody.result: This will delete the tag, but leave the text.

task.domains: (topic task) (topic hi-d) (topic ut-d) (topic indexing-d) (topic hazard-d) (topic abbrev-d) (topic pr-d) (topic sw-d) (topic ui-d) (topic task strictTaskbody-c)
task.title: Adding structural tags in the structural panel
task.shortdesc: In each document that you enter there is a pre-existing XML template that contains the basic tags necessary for that type document. You can add new structural tags to the document easily.

copyright.copyrholder: Use of this public-domain resource is governed by the Creative Commons Attribution-NonCommercial 4.0 International License

step.cmd: Select a tag in the structural panel and right click.
This will bring up a menu with three options that allow you to insert a tag.

choices.choice: Insert Tag Beforeallows you to insert a tag before the tag you have right clicked on.
Insert Tag Afterallows you to insert a tag after the tag you have right-clicked on (skipping over any nested tags within the tag you have clicked on).
Insert Tag Insidethis will insert a new tag nested within the initial tag yo clicked on.

step.cmd: Once you have selected one of the "Insert" options, choose a tag from the list that appears.
step.info: The tags that you can select, under each "Insert" option, are limited to tags that are allowed (according to the schema).

step.cmd: Once you select the tag you would like to add to the structure panel a pop-up appear that allows you to add qualifying information to the tag. Once you have finished, click on "OK."
step.info: You do not have to enter any additional information if you don't want to. You can just press "OK" as soon as you see this pop-up.

taskbody.result: You have now added a new structure tag.
taskbody.example: In the image below you can see we have added a new "time" tag in the document structure, by following the above steps.

task.domains: (topic task) (topic hi-d) (topic ut-d) (topic indexing-d) (topic hazard-d) (topic abbrev-d) (topic pr-d) (topic sw-d) (topic ui-d) (topic task strictTaskbody-c)
task.title: Creating a new person entity
task.shortdesc: The "Tag Person" option is for tagging people by name. It usually contains a proper noun or noun phrase, but can also contain pronouns or other ways of referring to someone.

step.cmd: Highlight the text that you would like to tag as a "Person." Click on the toolbar or right-click options (see images below).
Try to find the person you are tagging in the CWRC or VIAL.
If your entry is not in the CWRC entity lookup system you have the option to create your own. To do this click on "Create New Person" button at the bottom of that page.
An "Add Person" pop-up appears, fill it out (see note) and click "OK."
step.info: The only mandatory field is the "Person Name," though there are many other areas that you can fill out.

step.cmd: Once you have created a person entry in the CWRC entity repository, you can now add more information about the tag (precision, person type, etc.). Click on "Save."

taskbody.result: You have now created a new CWRC entity entry, you can use this creation the next time that you go to tag this person.

task.domains: (topic task) (topic hi-d) (topic ut-d) (topic indexing-d) (topic hazard-d) (topic abbrev-d) (topic pr-d) (topic sw-d) (topic ui-d) (topic task strictTaskbody-c)
task.title: Creating a new place entity
task.shortdesc: Tag place is for tagging a place. It can describe both a geological location or a setting.

copyright.copyrholder: Use of this public-domain resource is governed by the Creative Commons Attribution-NonCommercial 4.0 International License

step.cmd: Highlight the text that you would like to tag as a "Place." Click on the toolbar or right-click options (see image below).
Try to find the place you are tagging in the CWRC or GeoNames entries.
If your entry is not in the CWRC entity lookup system you have the option to create your own. To do this click on "Create New Place" button at the bottom of that page.
An "Add Place" pop-up appears, fill it out (see note) and click "OK."
step.info: The only mandatory field is the place name, though there are many other areas that you can fill out.

step.cmd: Once you have created a place entry in the CWRC entity repository, you can now add more information about the tag (precision, person type, etc.). Click on "Save."

taskbody.result: You have now created a new CWRC entity entry, you can use this creation the next time that you go to tag this person.

task.domains: (topic task) (topic hi-d) (topic ut-d) (topic indexing-d) (topic hazard-d) (topic abbrev-d) (topic pr-d) (topic sw-d) (topic ui-d) (topic task strictTaskbody-c)
task.title: Creating a date entity
task.shortdesc: The "Tag Date" is for tagging a date in the text. This tag can contain the year, month, day or a combination of the three.

copyright.copyrholder: Use of this public-domain resource is governed by the Creative Commons Attribution-NonCommercial 4.0 International License

step.cmd: Highlight the text that you would like to tag as a "Date." Click on the toolbar or right-click options (see images below).
Enter the date or the date range into the pop-up, and any additional available information.

taskbody.result: You have added a date entity tag to the document.

task.domains: (topic task) (topic hi-d) (topic ut-d) (topic indexing-d) (topic hazard-d) (topic abbrev-d) (topic pr-d) (topic sw-d) (topic ui-d) (topic task strictTaskbody-c)
task.title: Creating an organization entity
task.shortdesc: The "Tag Organization" entity is used to tag an organization or company.

copyright.copyrholder: Use of this public-domain resource is governed by the Creative Commons Attribution-NonCommercial 4.0 International License

step.cmd: Highlight the text that you would like to tag as an "Organization." Click on the toolbar or the right-click options (see images below).
Try to find the organization that you are tagging in the CWRC or VIAF
If your entry is not in the CWRC entity lookup system you have the option to create your own. To do this click on "Create New Organization" button at the bottom of that page.
An "Add Organization" pop-up appears, fill it out (see info) and click "OK."
step.info: The only mandatory field is the "Organization name," though there are many other areas that you can fill out.

step.cmd: Once you have created an organization entry in the CWRC entity repository, you can now add more information about the tag (precision, etc). Click on "Save."

taskbody.result: You have now created a new CWRC entity entry, you can use this creation the next time that you go to tag this entry.

task.domains: (topic task) (topic hi-d) (topic ut-d) (topic indexing-d) (topic hazard-d) (topic abbrev-d) (topic pr-d) (topic sw-d) (topic ui-d) (topic task strictTaskbody-c)
task.title: Creating a new text/title entity
task.shortdesc: The "Tag Text/Title" entity is for tagging a title or the text of any type of work

copyright.copyrholder: Use of this public-domain resource is governed by the Creative Commons Attribution-NonCommercial 4.0 International License

step.cmd: Highlight the text that you would like to tag as a "Text/Title." Click on the toolbar or right-click options (see images below).
Try to find the text/title you are tagging in the CWRC or VIAF.
If your entry is not in the CWRC entity lookup system you have the option to create your own. To do this click on "Create New Title" button at the bottom of that page.
An "Add Text/Title" pop-up appear, fill it out (see info below) and click "OK."
step.info: The only mandatory field is the Title name, though there are many other areas that you can fill out.

step.cmd: Once you have created an text/title entry in the CWRC entity repository, you can now add more information about the tag (author, date, etc). Click on "Save."

taskbody.result: You have now created a new CWRC entity entry, you can use this creation the next time that you go to tag this entity.

task.domains: (topic task) (topic hi-d) (topic ut-d) (topic indexing-d) (topic hazard-d) (topic abbrev-d) (topic pr-d) (topic sw-d) (topic ui-d) (topic task strictTaskbody-c)
task.title: Creating a link entity
task.shortdesc: The "Tag Link" entity is for tagging any links or URL found in the document.

copyright.copyrholder: Use of this public-domain resource is governed by the Creative Commons Attribution-NonCommercial 4.0 International License

step.cmd: Highlight the text that you would like to tag as a "Link." Click on the toolbar "Link" icon.
Write the link in the text bar, and click "Save."

taskbody.result: You have added a link to your document. You can access the link in either the document and the entities column.

task.domains: (topic task) (topic hi-d) (topic ut-d) (topic indexing-d) (topic hazard-d) (topic abbrev-d) (topic pr-d) (topic sw-d) (topic ui-d) (topic task strictTaskbody-c)
task.title: Creating a keyword entity
task.shortdesc: The "Tag Keyword" entity is tagging any important keywords in your document.

copyright.copyrholder: Use of this public-domain resource is governed by the Creative Commons Attribution-NonCommercial 4.0 International License

step.cmd: Highlight the text that you would like to tag as a "Keyword." Click on the toolbar "Keyword" icon.
Write the keyword in the text bar, and click "Save."

task.domains: (topic task) (topic hi-d) (topic ut-d) (topic indexing-d) (topic hazard-d) (topic abbrev-d) (topic pr-d) (topic sw-d) (topic ui-d) (topic task strictTaskbody-c)
task.title: Creating a correction entity
task.shortdesc: The "Tag Correction" entity is used to tag any correction you have made to the original text.

copyright.copyrholder: Use of this public-domain resource is governed by the Creative Commons Attribution-NonCommercial 4.0 International License

step.cmd: Highlight the text that you would like to tag as a "Correction." Click on the toolbar "Correction" icon.
Write the correction in the text bar, and click "Save."

taskbody.result: You have added a correction to your document. You can access the correction for edits in either the document and the entities column.

task.domains: (topic task) (topic hi-d) (topic ut-d) (topic indexing-d) (topic hazard-d) (topic abbrev-d) (topic pr-d) (topic sw-d) (topic ui-d) (topic task strictTaskbody-c)
task.title: Creating note entities
task.shortdesc: Notes must be applied to a span of text. They cannot be inserted into the text without the cursor having selected something, although they will be in the future.

copyright.copyrholder: Use of this public-domain resource is governed by the Creative Commons Attribution-NonCommercial 4.0 International License

step.cmd: Highlight the text that you would like to add a note to.
Click on the toolbar icon "Tag Note" or right-click on the text and choose "Tag Note."
A mini-editor will pop-up, enter any information that you would like in the pop-up.
step.info: There is a specific way to add text within tags in the mini-editor. To do this, you click the tag twice in the structure/markup tree, so that its entry is italicized (this means the tag's content is selected). you can then start typing, which will add text content to that tag. When using the mini-editor you can add XML and RDF tags just like in the main editor, though the toolbar options are limited (e.g. you cannot choose to "save" or "validate" the note). The structure and entity panels on the left mimic the structure panel in the editor and displays all the tags you added to the note in the mini-editor.

step.cmd: Once you have entered the text into the editor, you can begin to tag the document. Adding structural tags and entities to the document.
If/When you decide to add entities to your note, you will see a pop-up exactly like that in the CWRC-Writer.
Once you have finished creating your note, click on "Save."

taskbody.result: You have now created a note in your document. You can see in the image below that the note appears in the document, currently the note does not format correctly in the CWRC-Writer.

task.domains: (topic task) (topic hi-d) (topic ut-d) (topic indexing-d) (topic hazard-d) (topic abbrev-d) (topic pr-d) (topic sw-d) (topic ui-d) (topic task strictTaskbody-c)
task.title: Creating citation entities
task.shortdesc: tag citation is for tagging citations in the text, which may contain a loosely structured bibliographic citation of which the subcomponents may or may not be explicitly tagged.

copyright.copyrholder: Use of this public-domain resource is governed by the Creative Commons Attribution-NonCommercial 4.0 International License

step.cmd: Highlight the text that you would like to add a citation to and right-click or use the toolbar icon.
A pop-up will appear with a list of titles from the CWRC and VIAF entries. Choose an option and click on "Select."
A mini-editor will pop-up, enter any information that you would like in the pop-up.
step.info: There is a specific way to add text within tags in the mini-editor. To do this, you click the tag twice in the structure/markup tree, so that its entry is italicized (this means the tag's content is selected). You can then start typing, which will add text content to that tag. When using the mini-editor you can add XML and RDF tags just like in the main editor. though the toolbar options are limited (e.g. you cannot choose to "save" or "validate" the citation). The structure and entity panels on the left mimic the structure panel in the editor and displays all the tags you added to the citation in the mini-editor.

step.cmd: Once you have entered the text into the editor, you con begin to tag the document. Adding structural tags and entities to the document.
If/When you decide to add entities to your citation, you will see a pop-up exactly like that in CWRC-Writer.
Once you have finished creating the citation, click on "Save."

taskbody.result: You have now created a citation in your document. You can see in the image below that the note appears in the document, currently the note does not format correctly in CWRC-Writer.

task.domains: (topic task) (topic hi-d) (topic ut-d) (topic indexing-d) (topic hazard-d) (topic abbrev-d) (topic pr-d) (topic sw-d) (topic ui-d) (topic task strictTaskbody-c)
task.title: Deleting entities from the editor
task.shortdesc: The CWRC-Writer templates come with pre existing entities as examples to new users. You can easily delete these entities or any entities that you don't want in your document from within the editor (using right-click).

copyright.copyrholder: Use of this public-domain resource is governed by the Creative Commons Attribution-NonCommercial 4.0 International License

step.cmd: Highlight the text that is within the entity that you would like to delete.
step.info: Currently, removing an entity from the document that deletes the text as well.

step.cmd: Right-click on the highlighted text and choose the "Remove Tag" option.

taskbody.result: This will delete both the entity record in the left column and the entity (with text) in the document.

task.domains: (topic task) (topic hi-d) (topic ut-d) (topic indexing-d) (topic hazard-d) (topic abbrev-d) (topic pr-d) (topic sw-d) (topic ui-d) (topic task strictTaskbody-c)
task.title: Deleting entities from the entities panel
task.shortdesc: The CWRC-Writer templates come with pre existing entities as examples to new users. You can easily delete these entities or any entities that you don't want in you document or those you have mistakenly added from the entities panel.

copyright.copyrholder: Use of this public-domain resource is governed by the Creative Commons Attribution-NonCommercial 4.0 International License

step.cmd: Right-click on the entity that you want to delete in the left hand "Entities" column and choose the "Remove Entity" option.
step.info: Currently, removing an entity from the document deletes the text as well.

taskbody.result: This will delete both the entity record in the left column and the entity (with text) in the document.

task.domains: (topic task) (topic hi-d) (topic ut-d) (topic indexing-d) (topic hazard-d) (topic abbrev-d) (topic pr-d) (topic sw-d) (topic ui-d) (topic task strictTaskbody-c)
task.title: Deleting entities from the toolbar
task.shortdesc: The CWRC-Writer templates come with pre existing entities as example to new users. You can easily delete these entities or any entities that you don't want in your document from the toolbar.

copyright.copyrholder: Use of this public-domain resource is governed by the Creative Commons Attribution-NonCommercial 4.0 International License

step.cmd: Highlight the text that is within the entity that you would like to delete.
step.info: Currently, removing an entity from the document deletes the text as well.

step.cmd: Click on the "Remove Tag" toolbar button.

taskbody.result: This will delete both the entity record in the left column and the entity (with text) in the document.

task.domains: (topic task) (topic hi-d) (topic ut-d) (topic indexing-d) (topic hazard-d) (topic abbrev-d) (topic pr-d) (topic sw-d) (topic ui-d) (topic task strictTaskbody-c)
task.title: Editing entities from the editor
task.shortdesc: You can add qualifying information to the RDF entities added to the document. You can edit the entities within the editor by right-clicking. This information can be edited at any time.

copyright.copyrholder: Use of this public-domain resource is governed by the Creative Commons Attribution-NonCommercial 4.0 International License

step.cmd: Highlight the text that makes up the entity.
Right-click on the highlighted text and choose the "Edit tag" option.
Edit any information in the pop-up you would like and click "Save."
step.info: None of the information in the pop-up is required.

taskbody.result: The edited information will appear in the left "Entities" column. Click on the entry to see the information attached to that particular entity.

task.domains: (topic task) (topic hi-d) (topic ut-d) (topic indexing-d) (topic hazard-d) (topic abbrev-d) (topic pr-d) (topic sw-d) (topic ui-d) (topic task strictTaskbody-c)
task.title: Editing entities from the entities panel
task.shortdesc: You can add qualifying information to the RDF entities within the document. You can edit the entities in the entity column on the left side of the editor. This information can be edited at any time.

copyright.copyrholder: Use of this public-domain resource is governed by the Creative Commons Attribution-NonCommercial 4.0 International License

step.cmd: Right-click on the entity you would like to edit. Choose the option "Edit Entity."
Edit any information in the pop-up you would like and click "Save."
step.info: None of the information in the pop-up is required.

taskbody.result: The edited information will appear in the left "Entities" column. Click on the entry to see the information attached to that particular entity.

task.domains: (topic task) (topic hi-d) (topic ut-d) (topic indexing-d) (topic hazard-d) (topic abbrev-d) (topic pr-d) (topic sw-d) (topic ui-d) (topic task strictTaskbody-c)
task.title: Editing entities from the toolbar
task.shortdesc: You can add qualifying information to the RDF entities in the document. You can edit the entities from the toolbar at any time.

copyright.copyrholder: Use of this public-domain resource is governed by the Creative Commons Attribution-NonCommercial 4.0 International License

step.cmd: Highlight the text that makes up the entity.
Click on the toolbar button "Edit tag" to edit the highlighted entity.
Edit any information in the pop-up you would like an click "Save."
step.info: None of the information in the pop-up is required.

taskbody.result: The edited information will appear in the left "Entities" column. Click on the entry to see the information attached to that particular entity.

task.domains: (topic task) (topic hi-d) (topic ut-d) (topic indexing-d) (topic hazard-d) (topic abbrev-d) (topic pr-d) (topic sw-d) (topic ui-d) (topic task strictTaskbody-c)
task.title: Tagging entities in the editor
task.shortdesc: CWRC-Writer allows you to add RDF entities to your document. You can add these tags from within the editor using your mouse right-click button. When you add RDF entities to the document you are also adding a corresponding XML tag to the document.

copyright.copyrholder: Use of this public-domain resource is governed by the Creative Commons Attribution-NonCommercial 4.0 International License

step.cmd: Highlight the text that you would like to tag as a particular entity.
step.info: Currently, the events tag is not full functional.

step.cmd: Right-click on the highlighted text and select the entity you would like to add to the document. In this case we are adding a "Place" entity to the document.
Choose a CWRC, VIAF or GeoNames (depending on what entity you are tagging) entry and click on "Select."
step.info: The editor is now hooked up to the CWRC entity system. Lookup of all named entities (e.g. persons, organizations, places, and titles) from within CWRC is now available, as well as lookup in authoritative linked data sources. the external VIAF list of authorities, produced from national and major research libraries around the world, is used to link persons, organizations and titles, while GeoNames is employed in a similar capacity for place entities.You can also create a new entry in the CWRC system, this will be covered in alternate help pages.

step.cmd: Add any qualifying information to the entity (precision, identification, etc.) and click "Save."
step.info: The options that show up on this pop-up depends on what entity is being tagged.

taskbody.result: The entity that you have added to your document (along with any additional information you have assigned to the entity) will appear in the entities column on the left side of CWRC-Writer.

task.domains: (topic task) (topic hi-d) (topic ut-d) (topic indexing-d) (topic hazard-d) (topic abbrev-d) (topic pr-d) (topic sw-d) (topic ui-d) (topic task strictTaskbody-c)
task.title: Tagging entities from the toolbar
task.shortdesc: CWRC-Writer allows you to add RDF entities to your document. You can add these tags from the toolbar using icon buttons. When you add RDF entities to the document you are also adding a corresponding XML tag to the document.

copyright.copyrholder: Use of this public-domain resource is governed by the Creative Commons Attribution-NonCommercial 4.0 International License

step.cmd: Highlight the text that you would like to tag as a particular entity.
step.info: Currently, the events tag is not fully functional.

step.cmd: Click on the entity toolbar button that you are adding to the document. In this case we are adding a "Person" tag to the sample letter document.
Choose CWRC, VIAF, GeoNames (depending on what entity you are tagging) entry and click on "Select."
step.info: The editor is now hooked up to the CWRC entity system. Lookup of all named entities (e.g. persons, organizations, places, and titles) from within CWRC is now available, as well as lookup in authoritative linked data sources. The external VIAF list of authorities, produced from national and major research libraries around the world, is used to link persons, organizations and titles, while GeoNames is employed in a similar capacity for place entities.You can also create a new entry in the CWRC system, this will be covered in alternate help pages.

step.cmd: Add any qualifying information to the entity (Precision, identification, etc.) and click "Save."
step.info: The option that show up on this pop-up depends on what entity is being tagged.

taskbody.result: The entity that you have added to your document (along with any additional information you have assigned to the entity) will appear in the entities column on the left side of the CWRC-Writer.

task.domains: (topic task) (topic hi-d) (topic ut-d) (topic indexing-d) (topic hazard-d) (topic abbrev-d) (topic pr-d) (topic sw-d) (topic ui-d) (topic task strictTaskbody-c)
task.title: Adding relations
task.shortdesc: You can add relationships between the tagged entities within the document. You connect these entities with predicates, pre existing ones occure or you can add your own. This lets you create a semantic web of information within your document.

copyright.copyrholder: Use of this public-domain resource is governed by the Creative Commons Attribution-NonCommercial 4.0 International License

step.cmd: Click on the "Add Relation" toolbar icon or the "Add Relation" button at the bottom of the relations column.
Begin to add the relationships to your document.
step.info: The pre existing predicates depend on the first selected entity. For example, a "Place" entity has the available predicates "is located within" or "contains." Additionally, you can add your own in a text bar on the bottom of the pop-up.

taskbody.result: You have now added new entity relationships to your document. You can view these relations in the "Relations" column on the left side of the page.

task.domains: (topic task) (topic hi-d) (topic ut-d) (topic indexing-d) (topic hazard-d) (topic abbrev-d) (topic pr-d) (topic sw-d) (topic ui-d) (topic task strictTaskbody-c)
task.title: Deleting relations
task.shortdesc: If you have mistakenly added a relation, you can delete them in the left column.

copyright.copyrholder: Use of this public-domain resource is governed by the Creative Commons Attribution-NonCommercial 4.0 International License

step.cmd: There are two ways to remove relationships in CWRC-Writer.

choices.choice: Right-click on the entity that you would like to delete. Click on the "Remove Relation" option that pops up.
At the bottom of the "Relationship Column" there is a button called "Remove Relation." Select the relationship that you would like to delete and click on that button.
